title: Served as page at Wilton, and attended Salisbury School. Left St Alban Hall, Oxford, 1606 without taking a degree. Maintained links with Herbert family; Philip, Earl of Montgomery and later (1630) fourth Earl of Pembroke became chief patron. Although treats Catholicism sympathetically in his plays, political allegiances seem to have been more with ‘puritans’ and parliamentarians. Worked for King’s Men (1616–23); later joint author of plays with Daborne, Field, and Fletcher. After Fletcher’s death, the leading playwright of his time
